conclusion: To determine the maximum distance between Car A and Car B between the two instances when they are side by side, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
Car A travels at a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 0 to t = 30 seconds.
Car B starts from rest and accelerates uniformly to reach a velocity of 40 m/s at t = 20 seconds.

conclusion: Distance traveled by Car A from t = 0 to t = 30 seconds: d_A = 40 m/s × 30 s = 1200 m

premise: Car B accelerates uniformly from rest to 40 m/s in 20 seconds.
conclusion: The acceleration of Car B is: a_B = (40 m/s - 0 m/s) / 20 s = 2 m/s²

conclusion: Distance traveled by Car B from t = 0 to t = 20 seconds: d_B = 1/2 × 2 m/s² × (20 s)² = 400 m

At t = 30 seconds, both cars are side by side, so the distance between them is zero.

premise: The maximum distance occurs when Car B is accelerating and Car A is traveling at a constant velocity.

premise: Distance traveled by Car A from t = 0 to t = 20 seconds.

conclusion: The maximum distance between Car A and Car B: Δd = d_A' - d_B = 800 m - 400 m = 400 m
